Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
Gatherings limited to 10 indoors (with social distancing of 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 feet is not possible) and 20 outdoors (with social distancing 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 ft is not possible).  
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: - Fitness centers, gyms and indoor/outdoor sporting events may consider opening.
- Pre-screen and monitor employees for symptoms.
- Gatherings in facilities can be up to 50% certificate of occupancy for that room but no more than 250 people.
- Masks and social distancing required.   Source information: https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf
Luzerne County Policy Start
Other measures and details for this policy include: alcohol liquor stores open, paid sick leave

Policy_Details: Personal Services (i.e. Salon, Tattoo)
- Personal care services may consider opening.
- Operate under strict hygiene protocols.
- No food and beverage should be served.
- Masks and social distancing required.
Retail
- Employers exercise extreme caution, with employees working remotely when possible. 
- On-site work pre-screen and monitor employees for symptoms. 
- Masks and social distancing required.

   Source information: https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf

Policy_Details: - Enhanced cleaning and distancing protocols. 
- No symptomatic employees or children. 
- Congregate areas are closed. 
- Stagger arrival and drop off times. 
- Protocols for classroom/learning space occupancy that allow for separation among students and staff throughout the day to the maximum extent feasible
- Masks annd social distancing required.   Source information: https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf

Policy_Details: Individuals 5 and over must wear masks in Dane County when: in an enclosed space where individuals who do not share a living space are present; in line to enter an indoor space; using public transportation or hired transportation. Face coverings can be removed when eating or drinking; communicating with those hard of hearing; confirming identity; where state or federal law prohibits face coverings; and when obtaining services that necessitate removal of face covering. Individuals with with a disability, health, or mental condition, as well as individuals for whom a face covering would create a working hazard are exempt.   Source information: https://publichealthmdc.com/documents/2020-07-07_Order_8.pdf

Policy_Details:  Amendment No. 2 to Miami Dade County Emergency Order 26-20 by County Mayor Carlos A. Giménez signed 7/7 - all food service establishments with seating for more than eight people only allowed to offer outdoor (no indoor) dining. 
Outdoor service limited to hours of 6am-10pm. 
Table size limited to 4 people per table and music at low level or off.    Source information: https://www.miamidade.gov/information/library/07.07.20-amendment-2-to-26-20.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: Six additional counties were identified as hotspots within MS, adding the following counties to the county-specific executive order with tighter social distancing measures to help limit transmission (tighter restrictions than rest of state under "phase" 3, although phases not used to describe reopening in MS). 
Paragraph I of Executive Order 1509 is amended to add Calhoun, Holmes, Lamar, Montgomery, Winston and Yalobusha Counties. For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509.    Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1512.pdf

Policy_Details: Six foot physical distancing requirements for staff, volunteers, and worshippers for services and activities. Offer more protected areas for more vulnerable people and offer them separate areas of entry and exit. Limit the number of people in the service. Recommend worshippers refrain from hugging, handshaking, and other physical contact. Regularly clean and disinfect the facility. Encourage anyone who enters the place of worship to wash hands or use hand sanitizer prior to entry. Ask all staff, volunteers, and worshippers to self monitor for fever or symptoms of COVID-19. Ensure religious leaders always wash their hands or use a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol prior to conducting the service and any close contact or interaction with others. Consider whether to modify specific religious rites, rituals, and services, consulting with local public health officials as needed. Consider online collections or donations.   Source information: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stage1-protocols-worship.pdf

Policy_Details: - Heightened exposure risk and transmission is controlled in these areas. 
- Cases are reported but contained by rapid testing and robust contact tracing. 
- Social distancing and precautions are needed (maintain 6-feet distancing, avoid shaking hands, work from home when possible, reconsider unnecessary travel, wear a
face mask). 
- Increased cleaning on high touch surfaces and cleanings on shared spaces should be routine.   Source information: https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf

Policy_Details: - Fitness centers, gyms and indoor/outdoor sporting events may consider opening.
- Pre-screen and monitor employees for symptoms.
- Gatherings in facilities can be up to 50% certificate of occupancy for that room but no more than 250 people.
- Masks and social distancing required.   Source information: https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf

Policy_Details: • Indoor dining and drinking now permitted for parties of up to 10 people
• Seated areas should be arranged so that tables allow for 6 ft. between
parties; impermeable barriers may be installed between booths which are
less than 6 ft. apart
• Standing areas (in restaurants or bars) should be limited to no more than
25% of standing area capacity
• Buffets and self-service food stations (e.g. hot and cold bars, bulk items,
baked goods) should adhere to additional minimum guidelines
• Self-service beverage fountains are permissible with the additional
precautions   Source information: https://dceocovid19resources.com/assets/Restore-Illinois/businessguidelines4/phase4overview.pdf

Policy_Details: all restaurants and bars must close at 11:00 pm; tables spaced at least 6 ft apart; indoor tables limited to groups of 6; bar stools must be removed from the bar area (ordering, seating, congregating at bar area is prohibited); each party must have a reservation (even if made on-site) to ensure that the restaurant/bar has contact information for contact tracing    Source information: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-51.aspx

Stay at home, effective March 25 at 8 a.m. Gov. Tony Evers initially thought he would not have to issue such an order, but later changed his mind. “You can still get out and walk the dogs — it’s good exercise and it’s good for everyone’s mental health — but please don’t take any other unnecessary trips," he said. "Limit your travel to essential needs like going to the doctor, grabbing groceries or getting medication.”

Policy_Details: Six additional counties were identified as hotspots within MS, adding the following counties to the county-specific executive order with tighter social distancing measures to help limit transmission (tighter restrictions than rest of state under "phase" 3, although phases not used to describe reopening in MS). 
Paragraph I of Executive Order 1509 is amended to add Calhoun, Holmes, Lamar, Montgomery, Winston and Yalobusha Counties. For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509.    Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1512.pdf

Policy_Details: Emergency Order 13 by County Administrator: Following the footsteps of its South Florida neighbors, Palm Beach County beaches will be closed starting Friday through Sunday, ahead of the Fourth of July holiday weekend.

All beaches, no matter if they are municipal or private, will be closed. Restaurants and shops inside beach parks will be allowed to operate but must continue to abide by the mask mandate and physical distancing guidelines. 
12:01 a.m. on Friday, July 3, to 11:59 p.m. on Sunday, July 5   Source information: http://discover.pbcgov.org/PDF/COVID19/PBC-EO-13.pdf, https://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/20200629/coronavirus-florida-palm-beach-county-beaches-to-close-starting-friday, https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/news/2020/06/29/florida-closes-beaches-july-4th-weekend-covid-19-rates-surge/3277800001/

Additionally, no parades shall be allowed during this time period. Municipal firework shows may take place during this time period but only in strict compliance with the social distancing and facial covering requirements of Emergency Order 10-20 and Emergency Order 21-20, as amended. Policy_Details: - Heightened exposure risk and transmission is controlled in these areas.

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: Six additional counties were identified as hotspots within MS, adding the following counties to the county-specific executive order with tighter social distancing measures to help limit transmission (tighter restrictions than rest of state under "phase" 3, although phases not used to describe reopening in MS). 
Paragraph I of Executive Order 1509 is amended to add Calhoun, Holmes, Lamar, Montgomery, Winston and Yalobusha Counties. For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509.    Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1512.pdf

Policy_Details: Emergency Order 13 by County Administrator: Following the footsteps of its South Florida neighbors, Palm Beach County beaches will be closed starting Friday through Sunday, ahead of the Fourth of July holiday weekend.
Restaurants and shops inside beach parks will be allowed to operate but must continue to abide by the mask mandate and physical distancing guidelines. 
12:01 a.m. on Friday, July 3, to 11:59 p.m. on Sunday, July 5   Source information: http://discover.pbcgov.org/PDF/COVID19/PBC-EO-13.pdf, https://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/20200629/coronavirus-florida-palm-beach-county-beaches-to-close-starting-friday, https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/news/2020/06/29/florida-closes-beaches-july-4th-weekend-covid-19-rates-surge/3277800001/

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.

Policy_Details: Six additional counties were identified as hotspots within MS, adding the following counties to the county-specific executive order with tighter social distancing measures to help limit transmission (tighter restrictions than rest of state under "phase" 3, although phases not used to describe reopening in MS). 
Paragraph I of Executive Order 1509 is amended to add Calhoun, Holmes, Lamar, Montgomery, Winston and Yalobusha Counties. For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509.    Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1512.pdf

For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509. Policy_Details: Emergency Order 25 by County Mayor: Commencing at 12:01 a.m., Friday, July 3, 2020 and extending through 11:59 p.m., Monday, July 6, 2020 all public and private beaches shall be closed.
Additionally, no parades shall be allowed during this time period. Municipal firework shows may take place during this time period but only in strict compliance with the social distancing and facial covering requirements of Emergency Order 10-20 and Emergency Order 21-20, as amended. Policy_Details: Six foot physical distancing requirements for staff, volunteers, and worshippers for services and activities. Offer more protected areas for more vulnerable people and offer them separate areas of entry and exit. Limit the number of people in the service. Recommend worshippers refrain from hugging, handshaking, and other physical contact. Regularly clean and disinfect the facility. Encourage anyone who enters the place of worship to wash hands or use hand sanitizer prior to entry. Ask all staff, volunteers, and worshippers to self monitor for fever or symptoms of COVID-19. Policy_Details: All persons to shelter at their place of residence, other than to provide or receive essential services or engage in certain low-risk activities, which include: Performing tasks or activities essential to personal or family health and safety; Obtaining necessary services and supplies, including perishable goods food and medical supplies; Performing work providing essential products and services. Engaging in outdoor activity, including to take care of pets, go on a walk, or exercise--so long as you do not congregate in a group and maintain at least six feet of distance between you and other people;   Source information: http://www.acphd.org/media/572718/health-officer-order-20-10-shelter-in-place-20200429.pdf

Policy_Details: Personal Services (i.e. Salon, Tattoo)
- Personal care services may consider opening.
- Operate under strict hygiene protocols.
- No food and beverage should be served.
- Masks and social distancing required.
Retail
- Employers exercise extreme caution, with employees working remotely when possible. 
- On-site work pre-screen and monitor employees for symptoms. 
- Masks and social distancing required.

   Source information: https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf

Policy_Details: remote work for as many workers as possible: businesses and establishments shall institute remote work for high-risk individuals and shall evaluate whether additional workers can telework   Source information: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-51.aspx
Other measures and details for this policy include: religious gatherings exempt without clear social distance mandate, alcohol liquor stores open, keep firearms sellers open

Policy_Details: Pools: Limit the number of people in the facility at a time to ensure physical distancing. Limit use of indoor facilities. Direct the flow of patrons and employees through the facility to reduce person to person contact. Strictly monitor the use of the kiddie pool or other congregate areas.Thoroughly disinfect all surfaces and all equipment after each user. Employee face masks. Do not allow symptomatic persons entry. Use hand sanitizer or wash hands at the entrance to the facility upon arrival and departure. Provide soap, water, and alcohol-based hand rubs in multiple locations and routinely refill.

Gyms: Limit the number of people in the facility at a time to ensure physical distancing. Move activities outside if possible, and make sure there is optimal ventilation for inside activities. Direct the flow of patrons and staff through the facility to reduce person-to-person contact. Space exercise equipment at least six feet apart. Monitor employee health. Make hand sanitizer available at the entrance, in locker rooms, and throughout the facility. Shared equipment disinfected after each use.    Source information: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stage3-protocols-outdoor-pools-splashparks-waterparks.pdf

Policy_Details: - Fitness centers, gyms and indoor/outdoor sporting events may consider opening.
- Pre-screen and monitor employees for symptoms.
- Gatherings in facilities can be up to 50% certificate of occupancy for that room but no more than 250 people.
- Masks and social distancing required.   Source information: https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf

comments: Other measures and details for this policy include: alcohol liquor stores open, keep firearms sellers open

Policy_Details: HEALTH AND FITNESS:
• Capacity limit of no more than 50% occupancy
• Group fitness classes of up to 50 people with at least 6 ft. social distancing
between individuals permitted; multiple groups permitted given facilities
have space to appropriately social distance and can limit interaction
between groups
• Workout stations and equipment should be 6 ft. apart without barriers or 3
ft. apart with impermeable barriers in between
• For open gym spaces, have 1 employee per every 4,000 sq. ft. to monitor
social distancing and sanitize equipment between use
• Sanitize equipment before and after each individual use and sanitize locker
rooms and showers at least every hour
• Keep ancillary accommodations (e.g., saunas, hot tubs, steam rooms)
closed, though childcare areas are permitted to reopen in line with DHFS
childcare guidelines
• Members should wear face covering over their nose and mouth whenever
not exercising 

INDOOR/OUTDOOR RECREATION:
• Reopening select indoor recreation facilities (e.g., bowling alleys, skating
rinks); indoor playgrounds and trampoline parks should remain closed
• Indoor recreation to operate at lesser of 50 customers or 50% of
facility capacity
• Outdoor recreation allowing group sizes of up to 50, and permitting
multiple groups given facilities have space to appropriately social distance
and can limit interaction between groups
• Activity stations should be spaced at least 6 ft. apart or limited in number
to ensure social distancing
• Shared equipment should be disinfected before and after each use
• Clubhouses and other communal gathering places allowed to reopen
• Concessions permitted with restrictions 

YOUTH AND RECREATIONAL SPORTS
• Competitive gameplay and tournaments permitted
• Capacity limit of no more than 50% facility capacity, 20% seating capacity
for spectators
• Group sizes limited to 50 participants total (including athletes, coaches,
and referees); with multiple groups permitted during practice and
competitive games given venues have space to appropriately social
distance and can limit interaction between group
• Concessions permitted with restrictions   Source information: https://dceocovid19resources.com/assets/Restore-Illinois/businessguidelines4/phase4overview.pdf

Policy_Details: Six additional counties were identified as hotspots within MS, adding the following counties to the county-specific executive order with tighter social distancing measures to help limit transmission (tighter restrictions than rest of state under "phase" 3, although phases not used to describe reopening in MS). 
Paragraph I of Executive Order 1509 is amended to add Calhoun, Holmes, Lamar, Montgomery, Winston and Yalobusha Counties. For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509.    Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1512.pdf

Policy_Details: all restaurants and bars must close at 11:00 pm; tables spaced at least 6 ft apart; indoor tables limited to groups of 6; bar stools must be removed from the bar area (ordering, seating, congregating at bar area is prohibited); each party must have a reservation (even if made on-site) to ensure that the restaurant/bar has contact information for contact tracing    Source information: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-51.aspx

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: -	(Driving classes) Leave enough time in between appointments for an employee to disinfect all surfaces between participants
-	(Driving classes) No more than 3 participants and 1 instructor in a vehicle.
-	(Gyms) Spectators should keep 6 feet between household groups and wear a face covering if they can’t practice physical distancing, have chemical disinfectant supplies available throughout the building. Post signs asking customers to disinfect equipment after they use it.
-	(Retail) Removal of all previous restrictions
   Source information: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Utah_Phased_Guidelines_.pdf

Policy_Details: OFFICES
• Continue capacity limit of no more than 50% occupancy
• In-person meetings of up to 50 people with social distancing permitted
• Continue health screenings, though employers may screen office
employees via in-person conversation or questionnaire once at their
workstation, or using virtual method 

RETAIL AND SERVICE COUNTER
• Continue capacity limit of no more than 50% occupancy
• Mall food courts may reopen in line with Indoor Dining and
Drinking guidelines

PERSONAL CARE
• Continue capacity limit of no more than 50% occupancy
• If services require customer to remove his or her mask, employee
must wear both a face mask and eye protection (e.g., face shield,
protective glasses)
• No time restrictions on massage or other services

FILM PRODUCTION
• Capacity limit of no more than 50% of sound stage/location occupancy
• Crowd scenes should be limited to 50 people or fewer
• All individuals should maintain 6 ft. of social distancing unless job duty
cannot be performed without proximity (e.g. actors performing, hair, makeup, costumes)
• One-time nasal swab for RT-PCR testing of all cast and crew should be
obtained within 48 to 72 hours prior to the start of work on set or location
• Craft services and catering should follow Restaurant and Bar guidelines
• Live audiences permitted in line with Theatre/Performing Arts guidelines 

MEETINGS AND SOCIAL EVENTS
• Limit to the lesser of 50 people or 50% of room capacity
• Multiple groups may meet in the same facility if they are socially distanced
and in separate rooms
• Groups should be static for duration of meeting or event. If event includes
multiple sessions, participants should remain in one room, and speakers/
presenters should rotate between rooms or be digitally displayed (e.g.
projected, livestreamed) in multiple rooms
• Dance floors should remain closed
• Food service should follow Restaurant and Bar guidelines   Source information: https://dceocovid19resources.com/assets/Restore-Illinois/businessguidelines4/phase4overview.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
Gatherings limited to 10 indoors (with social distancing of 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 feet is not possible) and 20 outdoors (with social distancing 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 ft is not possible).

Paragraph I of Executive Order 1509 is amended to add Calhoun, Holmes, Lamar, Montgomery, Winston and Yalobusha Counties. For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509. Policy_Details: - Operate under heightened hygiene & cleaning standards.
- Monitor employees for symptoms.
- Large groups allowed such as festivals and sporting events. 
- Mass gatherings are permitted when following proper safety guidance and procedures.   Source information: https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf

Policy_Details: THEATERS AND PERFORMING ARTS:
• Seated theaters, cinemas, and performing arts centers for ticketed
events with seating available for all customers permitted; general
admission shows and/or events with standing room only are not
permitted at this time
• Indoor capacity limit of 50 people or less or 50% of space capacity
(applies to each screening room); outdoor capacity limited to 20% of
overall space capacity
• Patrons should wear face coverings over their nose and mouth, except
while seated within a venue (exceptions can be made for people with
medical conditions or disabilities that prevent them from safely wearing a
face covering)
• Concessions permitted with restrictions

OUTDOOR SEATED SPECTATOR EVENTS
• Outdoor spectator events only; indoor spectator events not permitted at
this time
• Tickets events with seating available for all customers permitted; general
admission shows and/or events with standing room only are not permitted
at this time
• Maximum of 20% of seating capacity for spectators
• Concessions permitted with restrictions

MUSEUMS:
• Capacity limit of no more than 25% occupancy
• Guided tours should be limited to 50 or fewer people per group
• Hands-on exhibits and touch screens should be closed or modified to
eliminate the hands-on component
• Audio tours are permitted, though equipment should be disinfected before
and after individual use
• Museums should have plan to limit congregation via advance ticket sales
and timed ticketing
• Concessions permitted with restrictions

ZOOS:
• Capacity limit of no more than 25% occupancy
• Guided tours should be limited to 50 or fewer people per group
• Hands-on exhibits and touch screens should be closed or modified
to eliminate the hands-on component
• Indoor exhibits should be closed
• Audio tours are permitted, though
equipment should be disinfected
before and after individual use
• Zoos should have plan to limit
congregation via advance ticket
sales and timed ticketing
• Concessions permitted with
restrictions   Source information: https://dceocovid19resources.com/assets/Restore-Illinois/businessguidelines4/phase4overview.pdf

Policy_Details: Pools: Limit the number of people in the facility at a time to ensure physical distancing. Limit use of indoor facilities. Direct the flow of patrons and employees through the facility to reduce person to person contact. Strictly monitor the use of the kiddie pool or other congregate areas. Thoroughly disinfect all surfaces and all equipment after each user. Employee face masks. Do not allow symptomatic persons entry. Use hand sanitizer or wash hands at the entrance to the facility upon arrival and departure. Provide soap, water, and alcohol-based hand rubs in multiple locations and routinely refill.

Gyms: Limit the number of people in the facility at a time to ensure physical distancing. Move activities outside if possible, and make sure there is optimal ventilation for inside activities. Direct the flow of patrons and staff through the facility to reduce person-to-person contact. Space exercise equipment at least six feet apart. Monitor employee health. Make hand sanitizer available at the entrance, in locker rooms, and throughout the facility. Shared equipment disinfected after each use.    Source information: https://rebound.idaho.gov/business-specific-protocols-for-opening/

Stay at home, effective March 25 at 12:01 a.m. As in other states, there are exceptions to the stay-at-home order in Hawaii, including leaving the house to go surfing and swimming. But the governor's office said violations could be punishable by a fine of up to $5,000, or as much as one year in jail. “The threat of COVID-19 is unprecedented and requires aggressive action," Gov. David Ige said.

Policy_Details: Measures in place to maintain six feet physical distance among patrons and staff. Signage recommending symptomatic people do not enter. Ventilation if possible. Disinfect common surfaces.  Prohibit self serve food items. Monitor employee health.   Source information: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage3-protocols-indoor-movie-theatres.pdf

Policy_Details: - Fitness centers, gyms and indoor/outdoor sporting events may consider opening.
- Pre-screen and monitor employees for symptoms.
- Gatherings in facilities can be up to 50% certificate of occupancy for that room but no more than 250 people.
- Masks and social distancing required.   Source information: https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: Six additional counties were identified as hotspots within MS, adding the following counties to the county-specific executive order with tighter social distancing measures to help limit transmission (tighter restrictions than rest of state under "phase" 3, although phases not used to describe reopening in MS). 
Paragraph I of Executive Order 1509 is amended to add Calhoun, Holmes, Lamar, Montgomery, Winston and Yalobusha Counties. For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509.    Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1512.pdf
Other measures and details for this policy include: keep firearms sellers open, paid sick leave

Policy_Details: On Tuesday, May 19, Bexar County Judge Nelson Wolff issued Executive Order NW-08 to supplement the existing Stay Home, Work Safe measures. These additional measures will take effect as of 12:01 a.m. on May 19 and continue through June 4, 2020 unless extended, modified or terminated early by the County Judge, and is consistent with Texas Governor Greg Abbott’s executive order and mandates issued by the City of San Antonio.   Source information: https://www.bexar.org/3234/COVID-19

Policy_Details: Governed by Directed Health Measures of the State of Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services. This includes weddings and funerals.   Source information: https://lincoln.ne.gov/city/covid19/pdf/directed-health-measures-2020-09.pdf

Policy_Details: Emergency Order 25 by County Mayor: Commencing at 12:01 a.m., Friday, July 3, 2020 and extending through 11:59 p.m., Monday, July 6, 2020  no parades shall be allowed during this time period. Municipal firework shows may take place during this time period but only in strict compliance with the social distancing and facial covering requirements of Emergency Order 10-20 and Emergency Order 21-20, as amended. Per Emergency Order 21-20, parks must close by 8 p.m.   Source information: https://www.miamidade.gov/information/library/coronavirus-emergency-order-25-20.pdf
